stream_context.summary: Kaze live-coded and play-tested Course 11, the abandoned power-plant stage, while showing a large new FPS optimisation, polishing the Block Boss, and prototyping a new weight-platform mechanic.

development_findings.summary: A 10–15 % framerate gain was achieved by replacing coin billboards with screen-space sprite rectangles, dropping CMD from 23.6 to 22.0 and bringing most of Bunny Brushworks to ~60 FPS.
development_findings.quote: Instead of having them be billboards, they are now rectangles in screen space… Most of this level is 60 FPS now.

development_findings.summary: Future optimisations may come from implementing F3DX3, which has not yet been integrated.
A textured blue star model now replaces the vanilla transparent star, giving collectible stars a distinctive look.
The Block Boss (Course 11) is functional; a new hit effect was added, coin placement tuned, and the team agreed to move soap refills to the outer grills for fairness.
Kaze outlined the full five-room flow of Course 11: mood-setting entry, weight-platform intro, treadmill room, timed electric slide, collapsing-grate corridor, and a final multitool star room.
Industrial photo references guide the power-plant look; grainy Mario Galaxy textures were rejected as ‘too noisy’. Plan to use vertex-lit electricity elements for atmosphere.
After Biobak’s suggestion, dangling platforms were re-imagined as paired counter-weighted elevators; Kaze coded shared-velocity physics and friction tweaks live.
development_findings.quote: That's a platform type that we don't have in this game yet.

development_findings.summary: Introduced explicit variable-field syntax in the codebase to expose memory layout and catch RAM collisions.
All music will be original; no tracks are being reused from other games.
Yoshi Milkman is supplying new SFX (e.g., grate footsteps, metal impacts) to increase immersion once integrated.
Indoor factory rooms may reach 30–40 k polygons because separate rooms can be culled; current model is ~3 k.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recently moved into a new house in Canada; streams from a basement workspace and jokes about being ‘enslaved to the bank’.
He holds a full-time job, restricting hack development; refuses to promise release dates.
context_findings.quote: I have a full time job, I can't dedicate that much time to just working on this.

context_findings.summary: Kaze lives frugally, claiming he rarely buys non-investment items and has done so since childhood.
Neck pain from today’s workout forced him to end the stream early.
Design philosophy: dislikes games built on tiny collectible rewards and opposes constant balance patches in competitive titles.
context_findings.quote: I don't like games that rely on having you find little treats. I want the game that rewards me with finding cool shit.

biobak.summary: Suggested moving Block Boss soap refills to outside grills, which Kaze accepted.
Proposed turning dangling platforms into counter-weighted elevators; idea adopted for Course 11.
Will handle texture work for the power-plant level; Kaze is deferring visual choices to him.
Participated in brainstorming humorous ‘union benefits’ dialogue for Bowser’s minions.

badub.summary: Responsible for composing a fully original soundtrack; not present live but referenced by Kaze.

zeina.summary: Zeina (Kaze’s wife) ‘banished’ him to work in the basement; playful personal dynamic mentioned.

key_stories.title: Sprite-Coin Performance Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Bunny Brushworks originally ran at ~42 FPS. By converting coins from billboards to screen-space sprites, Kaze shaved significant command load and lifted the level to nearly 60 FPS.
key_stories.challenge: Persisting framerate drops in visually dense areas.
key_stories.process: Re-implemented coin rendering; measured CMD reduction; live-tested with debugger.
key_stories.outcome: 10–15 % global performance boost and renewed optimism for further gains.
key_stories.key_quote: We found like a 10-15 % performance improvement. At this stage, that is crazy.

key_stories.title: Weight-Platform Mechanic Pivot
key_stories.summary: Originally planning dangling swing platforms, Kaze struggled with rope animation. Biobak proposed counter-weighted lifts, prompting a design pivot and on-stream coding of shared-velocity physics.
key_stories.challenge: Animating multi-height dangling platforms without complex rope logic.
key_stories.process: Brainstorm with chat; adopt Biobak’s idea; code friction, velocity sharing, and ground-pound behaviour.
key_stories.outcome: New, unique mechanic for Course 11 that doubles as a puzzle element.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we're going with that idea, yes.

key_stories.title: Delayed Bomb-Factory Rework
key_stories.summary: Kaze commissioned Mata to overhaul the Bomb Cap factory visuals, expecting a two-week turnaround. Four months later the work is still incomplete, creating uncertainty.
key_stories.process: Paid commission; periodic check-ins; promises of completion by June 1.
key_stories.outcome: Rework status uncertain; Biobak may review textures once delivered.
key_stories.key_quote: He is four months overtime on something that he said would take him two weeks.

key_stories.title: Balancing Dev with Full-Time Job and New Home
key_stories.summary: While settling into a new house and working full-time, Kaze fields audience pressure for release dates and manages limited programming hours.
key_stories.process: Streams from basement; refuses firm dates; implements features when possible.
key_stories.outcome: Project continues at slower pace; ‘done when done’ stance reiterated.
key_stories.key_quote: Guys, this releases when it gets done. Like, literally just leave me alone.
